concept.title: Links to Targets outside the Document

conbody.p: We need to balance between user friendliness and ease of maintenance.
If a target is another Eucalyptus file:

ul.li: Use the phrase go to: as in, "For information about all releases, go to the Eucalyptus Enterprise Edition release notes." Link directly to the target resource.

If you are referring to another document or resource multiple times in the same section:
Provide a link on the first instance.
Thereafter, don't provide a link, and use the phrase "refer to": as in "refer to the previously mentioned examples in the SDKs."
Never use "see" for an external reference. Never use "refer to" for a linked reference.
When referring to another guide by name, use the full name as it appears on the title page or title bar. Don't abbreviate any part of it.

conbody.p: When the referent is a link to a different guide or resource, but still available online:

ul.li: Use the phrase go to: as in, "To see a complete list of our discussion forums, go to http://open.eucalyptus.com/forum"

Always link to external network references like websites.
Exception: If the target is a page on the Eucalyptus website and this location is dead obvious from the context, adding the phrase "go to" isn't required.
Never use "see" for an external reference.

Use the <cite> element to indicate references to documents that cannot be directly linked.
These are primarily documents within a third-party website. We use this method because we have no control over the target location.
Rather than create a link that can break, link to the top of the website and direct the reader to use the local navigation to find the resource.
There is no standard for URL references for external links; you can use complete URLs or short versions as the context demands.
